definitions: lacking a bottom surface or base; open at the lower end
extending to an unlimited or seemingly infinite depth; immeasurably deep
examples: The magician pulled scarves from a bottomless hat
She carried her belongings in a bottomless bag
They stared into the bottomless pit below them
His appetite seemed bottomless at the buffet table

definitions: moving up and down repeatedly by rebounding from a surface
showing vigorous energy, liveliness, and good health in movement or appearance
examples: The bouncing ball rolled down the stairs noisily
Children were playing with bouncing rubber balls outside
The bouncing baby looked healthy and happy
She entered the room with bouncing enthusiasm

definitions: having the quality of bouncing back when thrown or compressed; springy and elastic
full of energy and liveliness; cheerful and animated in manner or movement
examples: The new tennis balls were particularly bouncy today
Children love playing on the bouncy castle
Her bouncy personality made everyone smile at work
The puppy was bouncy and eager to play

definitions: tied, fastened, or secured with rope, cord, or similar restraint
certain or destined to happen; obliged or compelled by circumstances
heading toward or traveling to a particular destination or direction
examples: His hands were bound behind his back tightly
The ancient book was bound in leather
She's bound to succeed with such determination
We were bound by contract to complete it
The ship was bound for New York harbor
All northbound trains are delayed this morning

definitions: having definite limits or bounds; restricted within certain parameters
enclosed or surrounded by a boundary line, wall, or other barrier
examples: The bounded set contains only finite numbers
Their authority was bounded by strict regulations
The estate was bounded by high stone walls
The park is bounded on three sides by water

definitions: having no boundaries or limits; extending infinitely in all directions
extremely great in amount or degree; seeming to have no end or limit
examples: They explored the boundless wilderness for months
The ocean stretched boundless to the horizon
Her boundless energy amazed all her colleagues
He showed boundless enthusiasm for the project

definitions: existing in large quantities; abundant and plentiful in supply or yield
giving generously and freely; characterized by generosity in providing or sharing
examples: The harvest was bountiful after the rainy season
The garden produced a bountiful crop of tomatoes
She was known for her bountiful hospitality to guests
The bountiful donor supported many local charities

definitions: relating to or typical of the middle class, especially in values and attitudes
having conventional middle-class values, especially materialistic ones; unimaginatively conventional
examples: They lived in a comfortable bourgeois neighborhood
The restaurant had a distinctly bourgeois atmosphere
His bourgeois values clashed with artistic sensibilities
She rejected the bourgeois lifestyle of her parents

definitions: of, relating to, or affecting cattle or the cow family
showing little intelligence or imagination; slow-moving and seemingly stupid like a cow
examples: The veterinarian specialized in bovine diseases
They studied bovine genetics at the university
His bovine expression showed no understanding whatsoever
She moved with bovine slowness through the store

definitions: curved outward like a bow; having a curved or arched shape
bent forward and downward, especially from age, weight, or emotional burden
examples: The violin had beautifully bowed sides
His legs were slightly bowed from years of riding
Her bowed head showed deep concentration
The old man walked with bowed shoulders

definitions: bending the body forward as a gesture of respect, greeting, or acknowledgment
curving or bending outward; becoming curved like a bow under pressure
examples: The bowing performers acknowledged the applause
Bowing guests entered the traditional tea house
The bowing branches touched the ground with snow
The shelf was bowing under the heavy books

definitions: placed or packed in a box or container for storage or transport
enclosed within lines or borders; formatted with a rectangular border around it
examples: The boxed chocolates made a perfect gift
All items were boxed and ready for shipping
The boxed text highlighted important information
She wore boxed earrings with square settings

definitions: having a square or rectangular shape with angular corners like a box
lacking curves or graceful lines; ungainly and angular in appearance or design
examples: The boxy car design was popular in the eighties
She wore a boxy jacket with sharp shoulders
The boxy architecture lacked aesthetic appeal completely
His boxy handwriting was difficult to read

definitions: having qualities or appearance characteristic of a boy; youthful in manner
having a youthful masculine charm or appearance, often suggesting innocence or playfulness
examples: His boyish enthusiasm was infectious to everyone
She had a boyish figure with narrow hips
His boyish grin made him look years younger
Her boyish charm captivated the entire audience

definitions: strengthened or supported with a brace or structural framework for stability
prepared mentally or physically for something difficult, unpleasant, or challenging
examples: The braced structure withstood the earthquake well
His leg was braced with metal supports
She braced herself for the bad news
The crew braced for impact as waves hit

definitions: pleasantly cold and fresh in a way that makes you feel energetic
giving strength, confidence, or energy; having a strengthening or restorative effect
examples: The bracing sea air cleared their heads instantly
A bracing walk in the cold morning air
His bracing honesty was exactly what she needed
The bracing effect of competition improved performance

definitions: containing salt but less salty than seawater; found where freshwater meets the sea
having an unpleasant or distasteful quality; slightly nauseating or offensive
examples: Mangroves thrive in brackish coastal waters naturally
The brackish pond supported unique wildlife species
The coffee had a brackish taste from sitting
His brackish humor offended some dinner guests

definitions: characterized by or used for boasting; superior in a boastful way
examples: His brag attitude annoyed his teammates constantly
She posted brag photos from her vacation

definitions: excessively proud and boastful in talking about achievements or possessions
examples: His bragging nature made him unpopular at work
The bragging winner irritated the other contestants

definitions: formed by interweaving three or more strands of hair, rope, or material
decorated or trimmed with ornamental braid; having a braided pattern or design
examples: Her braided hair reached down to her waist
The braided rope was stronger than regular rope
The uniform had braided trim on the sleeves
She wore a braided leather belt today

definitions: subjected to systematic indoctrination to accept beliefs uncritically; mentally controlled
examples: The brainwashed prisoners repeated propaganda mechanically
She felt brainwashed by constant advertising messages

definitions: having or showing exceptional intelligence; intellectually gifted and clever
examples: The brainy student solved complex equations easily
She surrounded herself with brainy colleagues daily

definitions: cooked slowly in liquid with the pot covered after browning in fat
examples: The braised beef was tender and flavorful
She served braised vegetables with the main course

definitions: divided into or having branches extending from a main stem or trunk
divided into separate parts or sections; having multiple subdivisions or offshoots
examples: The branched tree provided excellent shade coverage
Coral formations were intricately branched underwater
The company had a branched organizational structure
The branched pathway offered multiple route options

definitions: extending outward by dividing into branches from a main part
spreading out in different directions; diverging into multiple paths or options
examples: The branching pattern of rivers fascinates geographers
Branching coral formations covered the reef completely
The branching narrative offered multiple story endings
Career paths were branching in unexpected directions

definitions: marked with a hot iron to show ownership or origin; bearing an identifying mark
bearing a manufacturer's trademark or label; associated with a particular commercial brand
examples: The branded cattle grazed in the pasture
His arm was branded with the company logo
She only wore branded clothing from designers
The store sold both branded and generic products

definitions: self-assertive in a rude, noisy, or overbearing way; aggressively bold
acting too quickly without thinking carefully; impetuous and somewhat foolish
examples: His brash manner offended the senior executives
The brash young lawyer interrupted the judge
Her brash decision cost the company millions
Making brash promises without consulting anyone first

definitions: resembling brass in color or sound; having a harsh metallic quality
cheap and showy in a tasteless way; vulgarly ostentatious
behaving in a loud, forceful way without embarrassment; brazenly bold
examples: The trumpet had a brassy sound that cut through
Her hair had brassy highlights from bleaching
The brassy decor clashed with elegant furnishings
She wore brassy jewelry to the formal dinner
Her brassy personality dominated every conversation
The singer's brassy voice filled the nightclub

definitions: ready to face and endure danger or pain; showing courage and fearlessness
enduring or facing unpleasant conditions with courage and without showing fear
examples: The brave firefighter rescued the trapped child
She made a brave decision to speak out
He put on a brave face despite the pain
The brave survivors endured harsh winter conditions

definitions: bold and without shame; showing no embarrassment about behaving badly
made of brass; having the color or quality of brass metal
examples: Her brazen lie shocked everyone in court
The thief made a brazen attempt in daylight
The brazen bells rang throughout the valley
Ancient brazen shields decorated the museum wall

definitions: separating from a larger group or organization to form an independent entity
designed to break apart or separate easily under pressure for safety
examples: The breakaway faction formed their own party
A breakaway group of cyclists led the race
The stunt used breakaway furniture for safety
Breakaway glass is used in movie productions

definitions: dangerously or extremely fast; at a speed risking injury or damage
examples: They drove at breakneck speed through the mountains
The company expanded at a breakneck pace

definitions: having a breast or chest of a specified kind (usually in combinations)
examples: The double-breasted suit looked very formal
A red-breasted robin perched on the fence

definitions: uttered with breath but little vibration of vocal cords; whispered or spoken very softly
examples: Her breathed confession was barely audible
The actor delivered breathed lines for dramatic effect

definitions: living and drawing breath; having life and respiratory function
allowing air to pass through; permeable to air for ventilation
examples: Every breathing creature needs oxygen to survive
She was grateful to find him still breathing
The breathing fabric kept athletes comfortable during exercise
Modern buildings need proper breathing spaces

definitions: gasping for air; unable to breathe normally from exertion or emotion
causing one to be out of breath; extremely fast, exciting, or demanding
filled with intense excitement, anticipation, or wonder that affects breathing
examples: She was breathless after climbing five flights
The runner finished the race completely breathless
The breathless pace of the action movie
They maintained a breathless schedule all week
The audience watched in breathless anticipation
She was breathless with excitement about the news

definitions: astonishingly or overwhelmingly beautiful, impressive, or magnificent to behold
extremely exciting, impressive, or remarkable in impact or effect
examples: The breathtaking view stretched for miles below
She wore a breathtaking gown to the gala
The acrobat's breathtaking performance amazed everyone
Technology advanced at a breathtaking rate

definitions: producing offspring through reproduction; used for producing young animals
showing good manners and refined behavior from proper upbringing and education
examples: The breeding season begins in early spring
They kept breeding stock separate from others
Her breeding showed in every graceful gesture
A person of breeding wouldn't behave that way

definitions: having a gentle wind blowing; characterized by light, pleasant air movement
cheerfully casual and carefree in manner; relaxed and informal in style
examples: It was a breezy day perfect for sailing
The breezy conditions dried the laundry quickly
Her breezy manner put everyone at ease
He gave a breezy wave and walked away

definitions: of or relating to a bride or wedding; used by or for a bride
examples: She wore a beautiful bridal gown of white silk
The bridal party gathered for photographs outside

definitions: lasting or taking a short time; of short duration or extent
using few words; concise and to the point in expression or manner
examples: We had a brief meeting before lunch
There was a brief pause in the conversation
She gave a brief summary of the report
His brief response surprised everyone present

definitions: giving out or reflecting much light; shining with intensity or luminosity
having strong, vivid colors that attract attention or seem fresh and intense
showing intelligence, mental quickness, and exceptional ability to learn easily
full of hope and optimism; cheerful and lively in manner or disposition
examples: The bright sunlight hurt her eyes this morning
We need brighter lights in this dark room
She wore a bright red dress to the party
The bright colors of autumn leaves are spectacular
Their bright daughter skipped two grades in school
He's bright enough to solve complex mathematical problems
Despite the setback, she maintained a bright outlook
His bright personality lifted everyone's spirits considerably

definitions: shining very brightly with intense light; sparkling with light or luster
exceptionally clever, talented, or impressive in ability or performance
outstanding or magnificent in quality; inspiring admiration through excellence
examples: The brilliant diamond sparkled in the light
A brilliant flash of lightning lit the sky
She's a brilliant scientist with numerous discoveries
His brilliant mind solved the impossible puzzle
The concert was absolutely brilliant from start to finish
They had a brilliant idea for the campaign

definitions: filled to the very top or edge; full to the point of overflowing
filled to capacity with a particular emotion or quality; abundantly full
examples: The glass was brimming with champagne
Her eyes were brimming with unshed tears
She was brimming with confidence before the interview
The letter was brimming with gratitude and praise

definitions: having a brownish or tawny color with darker streaks or spots
examples: The brindle coat pattern distinguished the dog
She adopted a beautiful brindle greyhound yesterday

definitions: quick, energetic, and active in movement or manner; showing liveliness
pleasantly cold and invigorating; fresh and stimulating to the senses
examples: She maintained a brisk walking pace every morning
Business was brisk during the holiday season
The brisk autumn air felt refreshing outside
A brisk wind swept through the valley

definitions: covered with short, stiff, coarse hairs or bristles; rough to touch
showing irritation or defensiveness; quick to take offense or show annoyance
examples: His bristly beard scratched her cheek
The bristly brush was perfect for scrubbing
He became bristly when questioned about mistakes
Her bristly response indicated deep frustration

definitions: hard but liable to break or shatter easily; lacking flexibility or resilience
appearing strong but actually weak; emotionally fragile or easily upset
examples: The brittle twigs snapped underfoot easily
Ancient brittle parchment required careful handling
Her brittle smile hid deep anxiety
Their brittle relationship finally shattered completely

definitions: opened or pierced to draw out contents; made ready for use
brought up or introduced a difficult subject for discussion
examples: The broached wine barrel was ready for tasting
They broached a new keg for the celebration
She carefully broached the subject of retirement
The broached topic made everyone uncomfortable

definitions: having a large distance from side to side; wide in physical dimension
covering a large number and wide scope of subjects or areas; comprehensive
general rather than detailed; lacking specificity or precision in nature
examples: The broad avenue stretched through downtown
He had broad shoulders from years of swimming
She has broad knowledge of world history
The museum offers a broad range of exhibits
They reached broad agreement on major points
He spoke in broad terms about the plan
